Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Health services; policies and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was not taken to urgent care for medical attention until
Monday afternoon after punching a window on Saturday evening
despite visible swelling and complaints of pain in his hand.
Investigation The Complainant was contacted on 05/14/2024 and did not have
substantial additional information to provide.
The Program Director was interviewed on 05/16/2024 with
DHHS Worker 1 during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the
facility. He confirmed that at that moment Youth A was in the
hospital after he had been transported from school for self-
harming and assaultive behaviors. The Program Director
confirmed Youth A had punched a window in the evening of
05/11/2024. He received medical attention from a visit to an
urgent care site after school on 05/13/2024. The Program
Director stated Youth A had an appointment scheduled for
05/17/2024 with a hand specialist to determine if the boxer’s
fracture required surgery as a result of the injury sustained.
Youth B was interviewed on 05/16/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. He stated
that he saw Youth A punch a window twice on 05/11/2024, and
later that evening he believed he witnessed Youth A’s hand
beginning to swell up. Youth B also recalled Youth A was in his
room alone on that same date, and Youth B witnessed Youth A
punch a wall. Youth B recalled staff being nearby for both
instances of punching, but he could not recall which staff this was.
2

He believed Staff 2 was in the kitchen cooking dinner when Youth
A punched the window. Youth B recalled seeing staff members
look at Youth A’s hand and offer him pain medication in response.
Youth B stated Youth A was heard throughout the next day
complaining of his hand being in pain.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 05/16/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. He stated
he had worked the previous Saturday when Youth A punched a
window. Staff 1 clarified he did not witness Youth A punch
anything himself. He ended his shift at 10:00pm and stated he
never saw Youth A upset nor did he see his hand appear to swell
over the course of the evening.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 05/16/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at the facility. She
stated she worked the previous Saturday with Youth A. Staff 2
stated the punch of the window did not directly involve her, but
Staff 3 was present supervising Youth A when this occurred. Staff
2 recalled Staff 3 telling her that he believed Youth A needed to go
to the doctor after the incident. Staff 2 believed that it was Staff 3
that called Supervisor 1 to inform of the incident and discuss how
to handle it. Staff 2 believed a trip to urgent care was approved
but Youth A did not want to go at that moment. Staff 2’s shift
ended at about 8:00pm that evening and she recalled Youth A had
not been transported to urgent care by that point in time. Staff 2
did not witness Youth A’s hand herself. She stated she did not
work the following day and she saw Youth A on Monday afternoon
and witnessed his hand wrapped at that time.
Youth A was interviewed on 05/16/2024 with DHHS Worker 1
during an unannounced, face-to-face visit at a local hospital.
Youth A was being assessed at the hospital because he had
significant concerning behaviors earlier in the day at school and
the school requested, he be transported for medical care. Youth
A confirmed he punched a window by the front door to his cottage.
Youth A also recalled punching the wall in his room earlier that
same day. Youth A stated Staff 3 was with him when he punched
the window. He could not recall what Staff 3 did or said in that
moment. Youth A could not remember if any staff had asked him
to go with them to get medical attention for his hand after this
occurred, and he did not think he refused to go either. Youth A
stated he received Motrin the following day from an unknown staff
member to help with the pain in his hand. He stated he did not
receive any ice for his hand until the following Monday at school.
Youth A recalled his hand appeared to swell that same night after
3

the incident occurred. He could not recall if he told anyone that
his hand hurt. Youth A stated he had been wrapping his hand in a
shirt over that weekend and Staff 2 helped him wrap his hand at
some point, but he could not recall when.
A video conference meeting was arranged by the DHHS Foster
Care Worker for Youth A for 06/06/2024. During this meeting it
was confirmed Youth A was not going to require surgery for the
fracture in his hand and would more likely need a hard cast to help
it heal. It was also discussed that the wrapping and soft cast that
had been provided to him had produced difficulties because Youth
A would commonly remove them at the facility and at school.
Previous injuries for Youth A produced similar behaviors, where
he would not keep a soft cast boot on his foot when necessary.
Nurse 1 from the facility stated staff never told Youth A to remove
his wrapping or soft cast and he was doing this on his own.
Nurse 2, who works with the school in which Youth A attended
and not the facility, stated Youth A was commonly coming to
school with the wrap undone or too loose and school staff were re-
wrapping this on a daily basis. She stated Youth A informed her
he was not doing this on his own and staff at the facility had not
wrapped it well or at all on occasion.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker 1 on
06/06/2024. Staff 3 confirmed he had worked with Youth A on the
evening when he punched the window. Staff 3 stated Youth A
began to get upset at another youth over the course of the day
and this is what caused him to punch the door window located in
the vestibule of the cottage. Staff 3 recalled hearing Youth A state
that his hand hurt after the incident occurred. As an immediate
remedy, Staff 3 recalled looking for any ice bags and not finding
any. He believed there was another staff who was going to get
some frozen vegetables to act as the same for Youth A. Staff 3
stated he called Supervisor 1 after the incident occurred to
discuss how to handle it. Staff 3 recalled Supervisor 1 speaking
directly with Youth A, and Supervisor 1 did not give specific
instructions to take Youth A for medical attention at that time.
Staff 3 recalled telling Youth A that “if your hand is still hurting, we
will take you to urgent care.” Staff 3 believed Youth A stated in
response “Okay.” Staff 3 interpreted that as Youth A would tell
him if he felt like he needed to go, and that the decision to seek
medical care was with Youth A at that point. Staff 3 stated he did
not work with Youth A until the following Monday afternoon, after
Youth A received medical attention. Staff 3 confirmed Youth A
was not seen by any facility medical staff while Staff 3 was on shift
because the nursing staff does not work on weekends.
4

Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone with DHHS Worker
1 on 06/06/2024. He confirmed he was the on call supervisor on
the weekend where Youth A had this incident. Supervisor 1
recalled Youth A not wanting to go to the hospital or urgent care
after the incident occurred. He believed Youth A asked if he could
just take pain medication instead of getting other medical
attention. Supervisor 1 recalled giving instruction to Staff 3 that if
Staff 3 assessed Youth A as needing further medical attention, he
was approved to transport Youth A to the local hospital or urgent
care. Supervisor 1 stated Youth A never expressed to him that his
hand felt bad enough to need more attention. Supervisor 1 stated
to Youth A “If you feel like you need to go, just tell me you need to
go.” Supervisor 1 recalled Youth A’s behavior being confusing
because he would say that his hand hurt but he would also
horseplay and instigate physical activity with other youth and staff.
Supervisor 1 recalled he never told staff to not take Youth A in for
medical attention. Supervisor 1 stated he worked the following
day and he did not hear Youth A comment about his hand hurting,
nor did he witness Youth A’s hand and if it was swollen. He could
not confirm if he asked Youth A how his hand was feeling.
Supervisor 1 recalled Youth A horseplaying and playing football
on that Sunday.
On a video conference that occurred on 06/10/2024, DHHS
Foster Care Worker reported that there was concern over the
facility’s ability to help Youth A follow medical guidelines after the
injury. She stated the week following the incident there was a
hard insert that was provided to Youth A in lieu of an eventual
hard cast. DHHS Foster Care Worker stated this hard insert was
not wrapped to Youth A’s hand as instructed for that full week until
her next face-to-face contact with Youth A.
During a video conference meeting on 06/10/2024 DHHS Worker
1 stated her investigation was not yet completed and did not have
findings that could be provided.
Documents reviewed:
• Incident report documentation dated 05/11/2024 was
provided and reviewed. This was authored by Staff 3 and
approved by Supervisor 1. It stated Youth A got upset with
another youth and punched the front door glass, and in
response was given ice for his hand at approximately
6:30pm that evening. A question of was the child injured
was answered yes, specifically noting the right hand of
Youth A.
5

• Notes written by staff working in Youth A’s cottage from the
date of 05/11/2024 were provided and reviewed. It was
documented by Staff 3 that Youth A had hurt his hand
hitting a window and he was given an ice pack.
• There was no documentation gathered that referenced
Youth A stating any refusals to go to the hospital or urgent
care for medical attention at any point in time, nor was
there documentation gathered that detailed any staff
assessing Youth A as not needing external medical
attention.
• Medical documentation dated 05/13/2024 from Youth A’s
visit to Ascension St. John hospital was provided and
reviewed. He was diagnosed with a boxer’s fracture in his
right hand and follow up attention was needed from an
orthopedic surgeon.
• On 06/06/2024 the Program Director confirmed there was
no video footage that captured the act of Youth A punching
any windows or walls from the date of 05/11/2024.
• Facility policy titled “Medical Emergencies” was provided
and reviewed. This was last revised on 09/01/2021.
o A section titled “When to call 911” included
instruction to seek external medical attention when a
youth experiences a fracture.
o Further instruction for staff to not move the injured
part of their body if swollen.
o There was no instruction written in this policy and
procedure on how to determine if medical attention
is needed when a Youth appears to be in pain but
also states otherwise.
o In a section providing instruction on youth injuries
that do not require external medical attention it was
stated that staff are required to write an incident
report for all hospitalizations or injuries and where
there is any doubt of a situation to document it.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance with the rule cited as there
was enough evidence to support Youth A injured his hand to the
point of swelling, pain that required over-the-counter medication,
wrapping to support the hand and the facility did not ensure that
he received medical attention from the evening of 05/11/2024 to
the afternoon of 05/13/2024, when he was diagnosed with a
fracture of his hand.
Technical Assistance:
Youth B reported in his interview on 05/16/2024 that he had over-
the-counter pain medication in his room and offered this to Youth
6

A on 05/12/2024 because Youth A was stating that his hand
hurt. This was not corroborated by Youth A. Attention and
clarification on the policies and procedures for over-the-counter
medications in their provision and storage would help prevent a
youth from accumulating medication without staff’s awareness.
Further technical assistance was offered in the area of
documentation of a youth’s refusal of medical attention. If this
occurred it would be best to have clear documentation in the
incident report or cottage notes of what medical assistance was
offered to a youth and what their response was, and when staff
attempted to again offer assistance despite the youth’s resistance.
Consultation:
During the process of this investigation there was communication
between the facility, case management for Youth A and his school
regarding the overall care of Youth A. It was apparent there had
been some lack of communication between all parties on sharing
information of medical appointments and teaming of decisions
resulting from this medical attention, and consultation was
provided regarding the importance of that teaming to best
accomplish any care or medical follow through needed for youth in
the program.
Consultation was also offered around exploring facility procedures
in the event of a possible injury to a youth over the course of
afterhours or weekend times. Facility nursing and medical staff
are not available at those times and any exploration of how to
assess possible injuries outside of front-line staff’s efforts would
be beneficial.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
